image.altText: Coal rocks in the foreground with people in the background standing in high vis

items.synopsis: The Federal Environment Minister cancelled two projects over the failure of proponents to provide information on environmental impacts, which was requested over many years.

title.children: Queensland coal projects cancelled over failure to detail environmental impact

image.altText: Warren Entsch holds out both arms while speaking inside.

items.synopsis: Following questioning from the ABC, federal MP Warren Entsch said "an oversight" was to blame for his failure to declare thousands of dollars in gifted travel.

title.children: 'I appreciate you trawling through my records': Federal MP apologises for failing to declare luxury outback staycation

image.altText: A man is wheeled off a plane and into an ambulance

items.synopsis: The family of Queensland university student Alex Shorey say he is still weak, but has slept well after being flown back to Australia.

title.children: Uni student's long recovery after inadvertently ingesting rat poison

image.altText: A mixed media artwork of a woman with short hair, resting her head on her knee.

items.synopsis:
Sydney artist Julia Gutman has won the Art Gallery of NSW's $100,000 Archibald Prize for

her portrait of singer-songwriter Montaigne, titled Head in the sky, feet on the ground.

title.children: Julia Gutman wins Archibald Prize for portrait of Montaigne

image.altText: A woman and man walk past the Reserve Bank of Australia's headquarters in Sydney.

items.synopsis: The economy is already much weaker than the Reserve Bank thought it would be earlier this year. But will that be enough to stop it raising interest rates again, asks Michael Janda.

title.children: RBA forecasts harsher short-term pain for longer term gain

image.altText: Sign on a Medibank building in Sydney on June 9, 2011.

items.synopsis: Law firm Slater and Gordon launches legal proceedings on behalf of nearly 10 million current and former Medibank customers caught up in a data breach.

title.children: Lawyers allege Medibank failed to take reasonable steps to protect highly sensitive health data

image.altText: A woman with dark hair smiles

items.synopsis: Shaily Sharma spent years struggling to make ends meet after moving to Queensland. A new interim report finds more can be done to fast-track international health workers gaining employment in Australia.

title.children: Shaily was a dentist for years, but when she migrated to Australia she had to sell homemade meals to get by

image.altText: A quiet street in Shell Cove, Wollongong's south.

items.synopsis: Pointing to big changes that have greatly affected Australia's capacity to deliver rising standards of living, top economist Garnaut calls for a major policy overhaul.

title.children: RBA rate hikes creating inflation, top economist says, calling for radical policy overhaul

image.altText: Ms Lamb sits in a wheelchair and looks over her fence towards the camera.

items.synopsis: As talks about how to make the NDIS more sustainable ramp up again, people with disability say a good place to start would be with the costly and "exhausting" red tape.

title.children: Rayna needed a new wheelchair cushion. It cost $1,000 just to get the NDIS forms filled out

image.altText: A pine plantation engulfed in flames with a tornado of fire at the top of the tree canopy.

items.synopsis: Fire and research agencies hope a powerful new radar being tested will play a significant role in early warning about some of the most dangerous components of bushfires, including fire storms and vortices.

title.children: This mobile radar could save lives in bushfires of the future

image.altText: A framed photo of Father Bob with both hands touching his glasses is placed beside a table at the steps to the cathedral altar

items.synopsis: Premier Daniel Andrews and TV and radio presenter John Safran were among those who spoke at a state funeral for Father Bob Maguire in Melbourne.

title.children: Tributes paid to 'rebel' Catholic priest and social justice campaigner Father Bob Maguire at state funeral

image.altText: Three men look up towards the sky with mildly concerned expressions on their faces

items.synopsis: When video of a drone hitting the Kremlin hit Ukrainians' phones this week, many celebrated. But they are braced for Vladimir Putin's war to become more brutal and violent than ever, writes John Lyons in Kyiv.

title.children: Putin's war is about to get even more brutal. Just ask the locals

image.altText: man in suit and sunglasses

items.synopsis: Patrick Willmott is one of five people who have been found guilty over the Plutus Payroll tax fraud which saw the ATO lose $105 million.

title.children: Man who pocketed nearly $500k from ATO fraud jailed for nine years

image.altText: Chalmers points with his left finger, looking left to right in frame.

items.synopsis: Treasurer Jim Chalmers says he has not forgotten the nation's most needy as he prepares to hand down next week's budget which is expected to have a strong focus on cost of living support.

title.children: Treasurer insists nation's most vulnerable will benefit from federal budget

image.altText: King Charles and a smiling Anthony Albanese look at the camera as they shake hands

items.synopsis: The prime minister is putting aside his republican views to pledge allegiance to King Charles III to honour "the system of government we have", but believes the day will come when Australia stands on its own two feet.

title.children: Albanese says 'it's not up to me' to refuse pledge of allegiance to King Charles

image.altText: An orange sun sets over a city skyline, casting orange light across the horizon

items.synopsis: New data reveals how New Zealand households that have been under interest rate pressure for more than 18 months are managing to make ends meet.

title.children: NZ's interest rate is 1.4pc higher than Australia's. This is how it is impacting households

image.altText: A baby sitting up, smiling, with a book in her hands.

items.synopsis: Prader-Willi syndrome is experienced as an insatiable and dangerous hunger. But parents and advocates say the reality of the condition is far more complex.

title.children: There's more to 'smiley' Evie's syndrome than an insatiable, life-threatening hunger

image.altText: A close-up of the sharp hairs on the leaf.

items.synopsis: The agony caused by brushing against the notorious Gympie-Gympie tree can last for months, but researchers think its toxins may one day provide relief to chronic pain sufferers.

title.children: How a tree that causes excruciating pain could provide promise for chronic pain sufferers

image.altText: Riverine buffalo bull in the Northern Territory.

items.synopsis: An administration error by a third party has caused more than 2,300 straws of buffalo semen to be destroyed.

title.children: 'Big loss' as Australia's largest stockpile of buffalo semen accidentally destroyed

image.altText: Peter Dutton talks at a press conference in Alice Springs.

items.synopsis: Rogue Liberal MP Moira Deeming could be expelled from the party after threatening to take legal action to reverse her partyroom suspension.

title.children: Peter Dutton says Victorian Liberal crisis 'needs to be sorted out' as he flags federal intervention

image.altText: A tight head shot of an Aboriginal woman with dyed blonde hair.

items.synopsis: Margaret Hawke will learn of her punishment today for the murder of her three children, just hours after seeking support, in a tragedy prompting calls for more mining revenue to be channelled back into the Port Hedland community.

title.children: Her home town generates billions in exports, but Margaret Hawke couldn't find help before she killed her children

image.altText: F1 driver Oscar Piastri zips up his orange race suit while looking at the ground, before driving the Saudi Arabian Grand Prix

items.synopsis: Oscar Piastri looks to bounce back from an illness that hampered his last race, as Lewis Hamilton takes aim at Florida over LGBTQ+ stance.

title.children: McLaren upgrades have Piastri believing in Miami success, as Hamilton blasts Florida

image.altText: Penny Wong smiling, wearing a flower crown and lei over formal clothing

items.synopsis: A wideranging Pacific assistance package covering environmental, military, and economic support for Australia's closest neighbours will be unveiled in Tuesday's budget.

title.children: Hundreds of millions to flow as Australia seeks to counter China's growing Pacific ambitions

image.altText: Aboriginal man looking over old mission.

items.synopsis: Garry Ryder alleges he was abused while at Marribank Mission in Western Australia, but hopes the site will be restored as a reminder of Australia's dark past and so mistakes are not repeated.

title.children: Why this Stolen Generations survivor wants the place where he was abused restored

image.altText: Matt Canavan clasps his hands in front of him as a media pack encircles, microphones outstretched

items.synopsis: Nationals senator Matt Canavan has sought to link recent AEMO energy alerts with the closure of Liddell power station. But is there a link?

title.children: Are 'lack of power' alerts coming 'thick and fast' after the Liddell closure as Matt Canavan said?

image.altText: A lorry with a billboard of Julian Assange arrives at the front of a London court house.

items.synopsis: Giving his strongest comments on the case to date, Anthony Albanese tells the ABC he is "frustrated" the US government is continuing its prosecution of Julian Assange despite being "very aware" the prime minister opposes his ongoing incarceration.

title.children: US 'very aware' of Australian government's stance on Julian Assange's extradition, Albanese says

image.altText: A man scoops prawns into a plastic bag.

items.synopsis: A historic free trade agreement between Australia and the UK is set to be in place by the end of the month, following years of negotiations.

title.children: Australia-UK free trade agreement to take effect within weeks, relaxing visa rules and scrapping tariffs

image.altText: A husband and wife overlook their garden while holding a wheelbarrow.

items.synopsis: Many Australian retirees are returning to the workforce these days. For some, it's out of necessity; for others, it's for more philosophical reasons.

title.children: 'Who the hell am I now?': Meet one of the many Australians joining the great unretirement

image.altText: A large man wearing a suit and tie looks serious as he walks along.

items.synopsis: The disgraced former basketball star has admitted to raping the woman in two incidents, one of which allegedly left her in hospital with "life threatening" injuries.

title.children: Disgraced former basketball player 'Tiny' Pinder admits raping woman, in alleged 'life-threatening' incident

image.altText: An ASX board with ASX in focus and stock prices out of focus.

items.synopsis: ANZ and Macquarie bring in record profits. Australian shares bounce back in the wake of US markets falling on the back of growing concerns about the banking sector. Follow the day's events and insights from our business reporters on the ABC News live markets blog.

title.children: ASX up, ANZ, Macquarie record profits, Wall Street down on renewed fears about global banking sector

schema.headline: Live: ASX up, ANZ, Macquarie record profits, Wall Street down on renewed fears about global banking sector

liveBlogUpdate.headline: RBA takes another swipe at the "profit-inflation" argument
liveBlogUpdate.articleBody: The RBA has dedicated an entire chapter in this edition of the SOMP to the question of profits and inflation. It's already taken a few swipes at the argument that excessive profit-taking in the COVID era has contributed to some of this inflation. And today it's returned to the argument again, with a chapter titled: "Have Business Profits Contributed to Inflation?" And as a friend said to me, the short answer is Betteridge's Law. I'll say off the bat that, having reported on this issue, different schools of economists rely on different datasets, and interpretations of those datasets, to make their arguments. And according to the RBA's data, changes in domestic profit margins have not been a significant independent cause of the increase in aggregate CPI inflation in recent years. "For example, outside of the mining sector – where output prices reflect the balance of demand and supply in global markets – aggregate profits have grown at a similar pace to labour income, with some variation between non-mining sectors," the RBA says. "At the firm level, there has been little change in the distribution of margins. "These observations are consistent with firms having generally passed on higher costs to maintain their profit margins, and aggregate inflation having been driven by the balance of demand and supply factors – rather than changes in firms’ pricing power," it says. Here are some of the graphs it's included in the chapter:

liveBlogUpdate.headline: Causes of inflation
liveBlogUpdate.articleBody: The RBA's statement on monetary policy has some useful graphs that show which goods have contributed to this inflation with large price rises.

liveBlogUpdate.headline: New forecasts
liveBlogUpdate.articleBody: You can see the RBA's latest forecasts in this table. In each row, they have their new forecasts in the top line, and their previous forecasts underneath in parentheses.

liveBlogUpdate.headline: RBA's latest economic forecasts: growth and wages
liveBlogUpdate.articleBody: My colleague Michael Janda has a summary of the RBA's latest economic outlook. He says the outlook brings both bad and good news for Australians. The bad news is that the economy is much weaker, and households suffering much more, than the RBA forecast three months ago. But the good news is that this drop in real household incomes and consumer spending means inflation is coming down slightly faster than the bank previously expected. Before that story's posted online, here's some of the details. Near-term economic forecasts: The RBA says economic growth over the year to June is now expected to be just 1.7 per cent, more than half-a-percentage-point lower than was forecast just three months ago. Things don't improve before the end of this year, with growth of just 1.2 per cent expected over the year to December, down from a previous forecast of 1.6 per cent. Wages won't grow as much as expected: After much hand-wringing about the risk of a prices-wages spiral, the RBA has once again dialled back its forecasts of wages growth over the next two years. It forecasts Australian workers to receive average annual wage rises topping out at 4 per cent by the end of the year, before growth falls back again to 3.7 per cent over the year to June 2025. The broader measure of average earnings per hour — which includes bonuses, promotions and other factors excluded from the Wage Price Index — has seen an even larger cut to its forecasts, as employers report having less trouble finding workers to fill vacancies. The RBA's own business liaison suggests that, "Reported wages growth has stabilised and expectations for wages growth in the next 12 months have moderated." "Contacts report their wages growth has stabilised at around 4 per cent, but expect growth to moderate in the near term."

liveBlogUpdate.headline: Reserve Bank statement on monetary policy
liveBlogUpdate.articleBody: The RBA's latest quarterly statement on monetary policy has just been released. Here are the chapters for this edition:

liveBlogUpdate.headline: RBA's rate hikes creating inflation, Ross Garnaut says, calling for radical overhaul of economic policy
liveBlogUpdate.articleBody: Australia's economy has become increasingly dominated by powerful firms that are extracting "economic rents" from the system, economist Ross Garnaut is warning. I recommend getting stuck into this write up of Ross Garnaut's 2023 Bannerman Competition Lecture in Sydney on Wednesday evening from ABC News business reporter Gareth Hutchens.

liveBlogUpdate.headline: ASX 200 at 10:30am
liveBlogUpdate.articleBody: The ASX is trading lower on Friday. Ten of the 11 sectors are in the red. Banks, tech, miners and tech were the biggest drags. Utilities was the only sector in the green. Here's a quick look at top and bottom stocks:

liveBlogUpdate.headline: Market snapshot at 10:15am
liveBlogUpdate.articleBody: ASX 200: -0.2% to 7,176 points All Ordinaries: -0.1% to 7,371 points Australian dollar: Flat at 66.92 US cents Dow Jones: -0.9% to 33,127 points S & P 500: -0.7% to 4,061 points Nasdaq: -0.5% to 11,966 points FTSE: -1.1% to 7,702 points EuroStoxx: -0.5% to 460 points DAX: -0.5% 15,734 points Spot gold: Flat at $US2,056/ounce Brent crude: +0.1% to $US72.58/barrel Iron ore: -2.4% to $US98.85/tonne Bitcoin: +1.1% at $US28,902

liveBlogUpdate.headline: Global banking fears grow
liveBlogUpdate.articleBody: ABC senior business correspondent Peter Ryan unpacks the latest US banking woes as contagion fears grow.

liveBlogUpdate.headline: Medibank faces third class action over cyber hack
liveBlogUpdate.articleBody: Medibank is facing another class action over a massive data leak that exposed the sensitive personal details of millions of customers. Slater and Gordon is third law firm to launch legal action against Medibank. In a statement, Medibank said it "understands that these proceedings have been brought on behalf of current, former and prospective customers, authorised representatives of customers, and providers of health care services, in relation to the cybercrime event". "The statement of claim includes allegations of breach of contract, negligence, and contraventions of the Australian Consumer Law. Medibank said it will defend the proceedings. "Medibank continues to support its customers from the impact of the cybercrime through our previously announced Cyber Response Support Program which includes mental health and wellbeing support, identity protection and financial hardship measures," Medibank said in a statement.

liveBlogUpdate.headline: Macquarie's bumper profits
liveBlogUpdate.articleBody: Macquarie Group net profit r ose 25 per cent from September 2022 to March 2023 to $2.9 billion. Full-year net profit increased 10 per cent to $5.2 billion. Seventy-one per cent of the group's earnings came from international businesses. Shareholders will get an ordinary dividend of $4.50 per share.

liveBlogUpdate.headline: ANZ posts record interim profit, earnings on loans up
liveBlogUpdate.articleBody: ANZ's reported a half-year cash profit of $3.8 billion, up 12 per cent when compared with the prior half. Statutory profit after tax for the half year ended March 31, 2023, was $3.5 billion, down 1 per cent. Net interest margin (which is what banks earn on loans) increased 10 basis points to 1.75 per cent. ANZ shareholders will get an interim dividend of 81 cents per share, up from 72 cents a share a year ago. ANZ Chief Executive Officer, Shayne Elliott, said it was a record profit result. “This was a strong financial performance in  which all four divisions made a material contribution," Mr Elliott said. "The record result was driven by solid  revenue growth across the board and the benefits of having a well-diversified business." Mr Elliott also warned of tough times ahead. “The next six months will be more difficult than the last. Competition in retail  banking is as intense as it has ever been, both in Australia and New Zealand," Mr Elliott said. "We  understand that sustained higher inflation and interest rates create further challenges for  some households and businesses across the economy. While the number of ANZ customers  in difficulty remains low, we stand ready to help in these potentially challenging times.  “ ANZ also revealed 26 per cent of its customers are on interest rates higher than their assessed interest rate, which would make it very difficult to refinance. Yesterday, National Australia Bank's statutory net profit was just shy of $4 billion for the six months to March 31, up 19 per cent on the same period a year earlier. The bank's preferred measure of cash profit lifted to $4.07 billion, propelled by business lending and margin growth. The cash profit climbed 17 per cent in the six months ended March 31, compared to the $3.48 billion in the same period last year. The result was below market expectations. NAB declared an 83c interim dividend, up from 73 cents in the same period last year.

liveBlogUpdate.headline: 'Get your act together': A town's message to two of Australia's richest men as they struggle for control of a solar farm
liveBlogUpdate.articleBody: Business reporter Emilia Terzon travelled to the outback town of Elliott in the Northern Territory. Why? Well, Mike Cannon-Brookes and Andrew "Twiggy" Forrest are bidding against each other to control the $30 billion Sun Cable project.

liveBlogUpdate.headline: Apple sales down, just not by as much as analysts expected
liveBlogUpdate.articleBody: Apple reported quarterly revenue and profit above Wall Street's expectations, with iPhone sales rising and wearables sales slipping less than analysts expected. Apple said sales for its fiscal second quarter ending April 1 fell 2.5 per cent to $US94.84 billion. That was better than analyst expectations of a 4.4 per cent decline to $US93 billion, according to data from Refinitiv. Profit was flat at $US1.52 per share, compared with estimates of a 5.7 pe cent fall to $US1.43 per share, according to Refinitiv data. Apple shares were up 1.6 per cent in after-hours trading. The broader consumer electronics industry is grappling with a decline in sales of smartphones, tablets and PCs as consumers and businesses who bought up electronics during the pandemic, tighten spending amid rising interest rates and economic uncertainty. Apple also held its dividend and stock buyback programs roughly in line with its last update to them a year ago, approving $US90 billion in additional buybacks. Apple CEO Tim Cook said the company had set a fiscal second-quarter record for iPhone sales, thanks in part to picking up new users in markets such as India. "We were thrilled by our performance in emerging markets," Mr Cook said. "We set records for the iPhone-installed base in every geographic segment, and we had very strong 'new to' (sales in) emerging markets, particularly in Brazil, India and Mexico." Mr Cook also said supply-chain snarls had vanished. "We had no material shortages at all during the quarter across any of the products," he said. However, sales of Macs fell more than 30 per cent sharply while iPad revenue slipped. Sales in China also dropped 2.9 per cent to $US17.8 billion, a slightly larger drop than overall revenue. IPhone sales rose 1.5 per cent to $5YS1.33 billion, compared with analyst expectations of a 3.3 per cent decline to $US48.9 billion, according to Refinitiv. Those results occurred against the backdrop of a 13 per cent. Sales in Apple's wearables business, which includes devices like AirPods and the Apple Watch, fell less than 1 per cent compared with estimates of a 4.4 per cent drop. Apple's biggest growth segment was its services business, which includes products like iCloud and Apple Pay, which grew 5.5 per cent to $US20.9 billion, in line with analyst expectations. Mr Cook said Apple now has 975 million subscribers on its platform, which includes both Apple services and third-party apps, up from 935 million last quarter and an increase of 150 million from a year ago. - with Reuters

liveBlogUpdate.headline: EU hikes interest rates, signals more to come
liveBlogUpdate.articleBody: The European Central Bank slowed the pace of its interest rate increases on Thursday but signalled more tightening to come in what markets expect to be the final stage of its fight against inflation. All ECB policymakers but one, Austria's Robert Holzmann, supported the 25-basis-point increase in the ECB's main deposit rate to 3.25 per cent, which follows a series of 75 and 50-basis-point increases since last July. Inflation across the 20 countries that share the euro is still stubbornly high and the ECB was at pains to say that borrowing costs would have to rise further. "We are not pausing — that is very clear," ECB president Christine Lagarde told a press conference. "We know that we have more ground to cover." Ms Lagarde added that interest rates were not yet "sufficiently restrictive" to get inflation down to the ECB's 2 per cent target and made reference to future "policy decisions", suggesting that more than one additional rate rise could be on the cards. The ECB's shift in gear came just a day after the US Federal Reserve also raised its benchmark rate by a quarter of a percentage point, which it hinted could be the last in its own historic series of increases. The slowdown in the pace of monetary policy tightening comes only days after euro zone banking data showed the biggest drop in demand for loans in over a decade. This suggests that previous rate rises are being transmitted "forcefully" to the economy but with the usual lags, the ECB said, a comment economists took as a key justification for slowing the pace of hikes. - with Reuters

liveBlogUpdate.headline: Market snapshot at 7:10am
liveBlogUpdate.articleBody: ASX SPI 200 futures: -0.4% to 7,163 points Australian dollar: Flat at 66.92 US cents Dow Jones: -0.9% to 33,127 S & P 500: -0.7% to 4,061 Nasdaq: -0.5% to 11,966 FTSE: -1.1% to 7,702 points EuroStoxx: -0.5% to 460 points DAX: 0-5% 15,734 points Spot gold: +1% at $US2,058/ounce Brent crude: -0.2% to $US72.50/barrel Iron ore: -2.4% to $US98.85/tonne Bitcoin: +1.1% at $US28,902

liveBlogUpdate.headline: Wall Street drops on banking worries
liveBlogUpdate.articleBody: In the US, the benchmark S & P 500 declined 0.7 per cent to end the session at 4,061. It was its fourth-straight session of declines. The Nasdaq declined 0.5 per cent to 11,966, while the Dow Jones Industrial Average declined 0.9 per cent to 33,127. The sell-off came as fears grew about the strength of the US banking sector. PacWest's stock slumped more than 40 per cent in afternoon trading, dropping to a record low. Western Alliance shares pared losses after plummeting by nearly 60 per cent following a Financial Times report that the lender was exploring strategic options, including a potential sale of all or part of its business. However, Western Alliance denied the report, calling it "categorically false in all respects", and said it was weighing legal options against the newspaper. The bank's stock was down nearly 35 per cent in afternoon trading. Western Alliance has been seeking to reassure investors about its financial stability. It comes as First Republic's collapse, the third major casualty of the biggest crisis to hit the US banking sector since 2008, rekindled a slide in shares of regional lenders this week despite regulatory efforts to staunch the turmoil that began with the collapse of Silicon Valley Bank in March. US officials at the federal and state levels are assessing the possibility of "market manipulation" behind big moves in banking share prices in recent days, Reuters has reported. "Nobody knows where these banks should be trading at because what we saw with Silicon Valley Bank is that the fundamentals can change so quickly," Tom Plumb, portfolio manager at Plumb Balanced Fund said. "This normally would have been a great opportunity to buy banks with premier regional presence and it may be, but the real concern is nobody knows what the rules are and what they are valued at," Mr Plumb added. The KBW Regional Banking index dropped 3.3 per cent. Major U.S. banks were also losing ground on Thursday, with the S & P 500 Banks index falling nearly 3 per cent. JPMorgan's shares fell 1.4 per cent, while Bank of America declined 3 per cent. The common theme among the banking stocks that have sold off sharply is that they reported large deposit declines in the first quarter, said Truist Securities analyst Brandon King, while calling the sell-off "overdone." PacWest Bancorp reported a loss of $1.1 billion attributed to shareholders for the first quarter of the year. - with Reuters

liveBlogUpdate.headline: It's Friday, and investors are getting worried about banks again
liveBlogUpdate.articleBody: Morning all. I'll be with you on the blog today. US stocks fell on fears about the banking sector. A California bank PacWest has been "assessing its options" including a possible sale. The ASX is set to drop at open. I'll have more financial news for you shortly.

liveBlogStreamPrepared.name: Live: ASX up, ANZ, Macquarie record profits, Wall Street down on renewed fears about global banking sector

But the good news is that this drop in real household incomes and consumer spending means inflation is coming down slightly faster than the bank previously expected. Before that story's posted online, here's some of the details. Near-term economic forecasts: The RBA says economic growth over the year to June is now expected to be just 1.7 per cent, more than half-a-percentage-point lower than was forecast just three months ago. Things don't improve before the end of this year, with growth of just 1.2 per cent expected over the year to December, down from a previous forecast of 1.6 per cent. Wages won't grow as much as expected: After much hand-wringing about the risk of a prices-wages spiral, the RBA has once again dialled back its forecasts of wages growth over the next two years. It forecasts Australian workers to receive average annual wage rises topping out at 4 per cent by the end of the year, before growth falls back again to 3.7 per cent over the year to June 2025. The broader measure of average earnings per hour — which includes bonuses, promotions and other factors excluded from the Wage Price Index — has seen an even larger cut to its forecasts, as employers report having less trouble finding workers to fill vacancies. The RBA's own business liaison suggests that, "Reported wages growth has stabilised and expectations for wages growth in the next 12 months have moderated." "Contacts report their wages growth has stabilised at around 4 per cent, but expect growth to moderate in the near term."
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: RBA's latest economic forecasts: growth and wages

children.content: My colleague Michael Janda has a summary of the RBA's latest economic outlook.
He says the outlook brings both bad and good news for Australians.
The
bad news
is that the economy is much weaker, and households suffering much more, than the RBA forecast three months ago.
But the
good news
is that this drop in real household incomes and consumer spending means inflation is coming down slightly faster than the bank previously expected.
Before that story's posted online, here's some of the details.
Near-term economic forecasts:
The RBA says
economic growth over the year to June is now expected to be just 1.7 per cent
more than half-a-percentage-point lower than was forecast just three months ago.
Things don't improve before the end of this year,
with growth of just 1.2 per cent expected over the year to December
, down from a previous forecast of 1.6 per cent.
Wages won't grow as much as expected:
After much hand-wringing about the risk of a prices-wages spiral, the RBA has once again dialled back its forecasts of wages growth over the next two years.
It forecasts Australian workers to receive average annual wage rises
topping out at 4 per cent
by the end of the year, before growth falls back again to 3.7 per cent over the year to June 2025.

The broader measure of average earnings per hour — which includes bonuses, promotions and other factors excluded from the Wage Price Index — has seen an even larger cut to its forecasts, as employers report having less trouble finding workers to fill vacancies.
The RBA's own business liaison suggests that, "Reported wages growth has stabilised and expectations for wages growth in the next 12 months have moderated."
"Contacts report their wages growth has stabilised at around 4 per cent, but expect growth to moderate in the near term."

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Australia's economy has become increasingly dominated by powerful firms that are extracting "economic rents" from the system, economist Ross Garnaut is warning. I recommend getting stuck into this write up of Ross Garnaut's 2023 Bannerman Competition Lecture in Sydney on Wednesday evening from ABC News business reporter Gareth Hutchens.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Medibank is facing another class action over a massive data leak that exposed the sensitive personal details of millions of customers. Slater and Gordon is third law firm to launch legal action against Medibank. In a statement, Medibank said it "understands that these proceedings have been brought on behalf of current, former and prospective customers, authorised representatives of customers, and providers of health care services, in relation to the cybercrime event". "The statement of claim includes allegations of breach of contract, negligence, and contraventions of the Australian Consumer Law. Medibank said it will defend the proceedings. "Medibank continues to support its customers from the impact of the cybercrime through our previously announced Cyber Response Support Program which includes mental health and wellbeing support, identity protection and financial hardship measures," Medibank said in a statement.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Medibank faces third class action over cyber hack

children.content: Medibank is facing another class action over a massive data leak that exposed the sensitive personal details of millions of customers.
Slater and Gordon is third law firm to launch legal action against Medibank.

In a statement, Medibank said it "understands that these proceedings have been brought on behalf of current, former and prospective customers, authorised representatives of customers, and providers of health care services, in relation to the cybercrime event".
"The statement of claim includes allegations of breach of contract, negligence, and contraventions of the Australian Consumer Law.
Medibank said it will defend the proceedings.

"Medibank continues to support its customers from the impact of the cybercrime through our previously announced Cyber Response Support Program which includes mental health and wellbeing support, identity protection and financial hardship measures," Medibank said in a statement.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Macquarie Group net profit r ose 25 per cent from September 2022 to March 2023 to $2.9 billion. Full-year net profit increased 10 per cent to $5.2 billion. Seventy-one per cent of the group's earnings came from international businesses. Shareholders will get an ordinary dividend of $4.50 per share.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Macquarie's bumper profits

children.content: Macquarie Group
net profit r
ose 25 per cent
from September 2022 to March 2023 to $2.9 billion.
Full-year net profit
increased
10 per cent to $5.2 billion.
Seventy-one per cent of the group's earnings came from international businesses.
Shareholders will get an ordinary dividend of $4.50 per share.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: ANZ's reported a half-year cash profit of $3.8 billion, up 12 per cent when compared with the prior half. Statutory profit after tax for the half year ended March 31, 2023, was $3.5 billion, down 1 per cent. Net interest margin (which is what banks earn on loans) increased 10 basis points to 1.75 per cent. ANZ shareholders will get an interim dividend of 81 cents per share, up from 72 cents a share a year ago. ANZ Chief Executive Officer, Shayne Elliott, said it was a record profit result. “This was a strong financial performance in  which all four divisions made a material contribution," Mr Elliott said. "The record result was driven by solid  revenue growth across the board and the benefits of having a well-diversified business." Mr Elliott also warned of tough times ahead. “The next six months will be more difficult than the last. Competition in retail  banking is as intense as it has ever been, both in Australia and New Zealand," Mr Elliott said. "We  understand that sustained higher inflation and interest rates create further challenges for  some households and businesses across the economy. While the number of ANZ customers  in difficulty remains low, we stand ready to help in these potentially challenging times.  “ ANZ also revealed 26 per cent of its customers are on interest rates higher than their assessed interest rate, which would make it very difficult to refinance. Yesterday, National Australia Bank's statutory net profit was just shy of $4 billion for the six months to March 31, up 19 per cent on the same period a year earlier. The bank's preferred measure of cash profit lifted to $4.07 billion, propelled by business lending and margin growth. The cash profit climbed 17 per cent in the six months ended March 31, compared to the $3.48 billion in the same period last year. The result was below market expectations. NAB declared an 83c interim dividend, up from 73 cents in the same period last year.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: ANZ posts record interim profit, earnings on loans up

children.content: ANZ's reported a half-year cash profit of $3.8 billion, up 12 per cent when compared with the prior half.
Statutory profit after tax for the half year ended March 31, 2023, was $3.5 billion, down 1 per cent.
Net interest margin (which is what banks earn on loans) increased 10 basis points to 1.75 per cent.
ANZ shareholders will get an interim dividend of 81 cents per share, up from 72 cents a share a year ago.
ANZ Chief Executive Officer, Shayne Elliott,
said it was a record profit result.
“This was a strong financial performance in  which all four divisions made a material contribution," Mr Elliott said.
"The record result was driven by solid  revenue growth across the board and the benefits of having a well-diversified business."
Mr Elliott also warned of tough times ahead.
“The next six months will be more difficult than the last. Competition in retail  banking is as intense as it has ever been, both in Australia and New Zealand," Mr Elliott said.

"We  understand that sustained higher inflation and interest rates create further challenges for  some households and businesses across the economy. While the number of ANZ customers  in difficulty remains low, we stand ready to help in these potentially challenging times.  “
ANZ also revealed 26 per cent of its customers are on interest rates higher than their assessed interest rate, which would make it very difficult to refinance.
Yesterday, National Australia Bank's statutory net profit was just shy of $4 billion for the six months to March 31, up 19 per cent on the same period a year earlier.
The bank's preferred measure of cash profit lifted to $4.07 billion, propelled by business lending and margin growth.
The cash profit climbed 17 per cent in the six months ended March 31, compared to the $3.48 billion in the same period last year. The result was below market expectations.
NAB declared an 83c interim dividend, up from 73 cents in the same period last year.

liveBlogPostPrepared.title: 'Get your act together': A town's message to two of Australia's richest men as they struggle for control of a solar farm

Cannon-Brookes and Andrew "Twiggy"
Forrest are bidding against each other to control the $30 billion Sun Cable project.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Apple reported quarterly revenue and profit above Wall Street's expectations, with iPhone sales rising and wearables sales slipping less than analysts expected. Apple said sales for its fiscal second quarter ending April 1 fell 2.5 per cent to $US94.84 billion. That was better than analyst expectations of a 4.4 per cent decline to $US93 billion, according to data from Refinitiv. Profit was flat at $US1.52 per share, compared with estimates of a 5.7 pe cent fall to $US1.43 per share, according to Refinitiv data. Apple shares were up 1.6 per cent in after-hours trading. The broader consumer electronics industry is grappling with a decline in sales of smartphones, tablets and PCs as consumers and businesses who bought up electronics during the pandemic, tighten spending amid rising interest rates and economic uncertainty. Apple also held its dividend and stock buyback programs roughly in line with its last update to them a year ago, approving $US90 billion in additional buybacks. Apple CEO Tim Cook said the company had set a fiscal second-quarter record for iPhone sales, thanks in part to picking up new users in markets such as India. "We were thrilled by our performance in emerging markets," Mr Cook said. "We set records for the iPhone-installed base in every geographic segment, and we had very strong 'new to' (sales in) emerging markets, particularly in Brazil, India and Mexico." Mr Cook also said supply-chain snarls had vanished. "We had no material shortages at all during the quarter across any of the products," he said. However, sales of Macs fell more than 30 per cent sharply while iPad revenue slipped. Sales in China also dropped 2.9 per cent to $US17.8 billion, a slightly larger drop than overall revenue. IPhone sales rose 1.5 per cent to $5YS1.33 billion, compared with analyst expectations of a 3.3 per cent decline to $US48.9 billion, according to Refinitiv. Those results occurred against the backdrop of a 13 per cent. Sales in Apple's wearables business, which includes devices like AirPods and the Apple Watch, fell less than 1 per cent compared with estimates of a 4.4 per cent drop. Apple's biggest growth segment was its services business, which includes products like iCloud and Apple Pay, which grew 5.5 per cent to $US20.9 billion, in line with analyst expectations. Mr Cook said Apple now has 975 million subscribers on its platform, which includes both Apple services and third-party apps, up from 935 million last quarter and an increase of 150 million from a year ago. - with Reuters
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Apple sales down, just not by as much as analysts expected

children.content: Apple reported quarterly revenue and profit above Wall Street's expectations, with iPhone sales rising and wearables sales slipping less than analysts expected.

Apple said sales for its fiscal second quarter ending April 1 fell 2.5 per cent to $US94.84 billion. That was better than analyst expectations of a 4.4 per cent decline to $US93 billion, according to data from Refinitiv.
Profit was flat at $US1.52 per share, compared with estimates of a 5.7 pe cent fall to $US1.43 per share, according to Refinitiv data.
Apple shares were up 1.6 per cent in after-hours trading.

The broader consumer electronics industry is grappling with a decline in sales of smartphones, tablets and PCs as consumers and businesses who bought up electronics during the pandemic, tighten spending amid rising interest rates and economic uncertainty.
Apple also held its dividend and stock buyback programs roughly in line with its last update to them a year ago, approving $US90 billion in additional buybacks.
Apple CEO Tim Cook said the company had set a fiscal second-quarter record for iPhone sales, thanks in part to picking up new users in markets such as India.
"We were thrilled by our performance in emerging markets," Mr Cook said.
"We set records for the iPhone-installed base in every geographic segment, and we had very strong 'new to' (sales in) emerging markets, particularly in Brazil, India and Mexico."
Mr Cook also said supply-chain snarls had vanished.
"We had no material shortages at all during the quarter across any of the products," he said.
However, sales of Macs fell more than 30 per cent sharply while iPad revenue slipped.
Sales in China also dropped 2.9 per cent to $US17.8 billion, a slightly larger drop than overall revenue.
IPhone sales rose 1.5 per cent to $5YS1.33 billion, compared with analyst expectations of a 3.3 per cent decline to $US48.9 billion, according to Refinitiv.
Those results occurred against the backdrop of a 13 per cent.
Sales in Apple's wearables business, which includes devices like AirPods and the Apple Watch, fell less than 1 per cent compared with estimates of a 4.4 per cent drop.
Apple's biggest growth segment was its services business, which includes products like iCloud and Apple Pay, which grew 5.5 per cent to $US20.9 billion, in line with analyst expectations.

Mr Cook said Apple now has 975 million subscribers on its platform, which includes both Apple services and third-party apps, up from 935 million last quarter and an increase of 150 million from a year ago.
- with Reuters

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: The European Central Bank slowed the pace of its interest rate increases on Thursday but signalled more tightening to come in what markets expect to be the final stage of its fight against inflation. All ECB policymakers but one, Austria's Robert Holzmann, supported the 25-basis-point increase in the ECB's main deposit rate to 3.25 per cent, which follows a series of 75 and 50-basis-point increases since last July. Inflation across the 20 countries that share the euro is still stubbornly high and the ECB was at pains to say that borrowing costs would have to rise further. "We are not pausing — that is very clear," ECB president Christine Lagarde told a press conference. "We know that we have more ground to cover." Ms Lagarde added that interest rates were not yet "sufficiently restrictive" to get inflation down to the ECB's 2 per cent target and made reference to future "policy decisions", suggesting that more than one additional rate rise could be on the cards. The ECB's shift in gear came just a day after the US Federal Reserve also raised its benchmark rate by a quarter of a percentage point, which it hinted could be the last in its own historic series of increases. The slowdown in the pace of monetary policy tightening comes only days after euro zone banking data showed the biggest drop in demand for loans in over a decade. This suggests that previous rate rises are being transmitted "forcefully" to the economy but with the usual lags, the ECB said, a comment economists took as a key justification for slowing the pace of hikes. - with Reuters
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: EU hikes interest rates, signals more to come

children.content: The European Central Bank slowed the pace of its interest rate increases on Thursday but signalled more tightening to come in what markets expect to be the final stage of its fight against inflation.
All ECB policymakers but one, Austria's Robert Holzmann, supported
the 25-basis-point increase in the ECB's main deposit rate to 3.25 per cent, which follows a series of 75 and 50-basis-point increases since last July.
Inflation across the 20 countries that share the euro is still stubbornly high and the ECB was at pains to say that borrowing costs would have to rise further.
"We are not pausing — that is very clear," ECB president Christine Lagarde told a press conference.
"We know that we have more ground to cover."

Ms Lagarde added that interest rates were not yet "sufficiently restrictive" to get inflation down to the ECB's 2 per cent target and made reference to future "policy decisions", suggesting that more than one additional rate rise could be on the cards.
The ECB's shift in gear came just a day after the US Federal Reserve also raised its benchmark rate by a quarter of a percentage point, which it hinted
could be the last in its own historic series of increases.
The slowdown in the pace of monetary policy tightening comes only days after euro zone banking data showed the biggest drop in demand for loans in over a decade.

This suggests that previous rate rises are being transmitted "forcefully" to the economy but with the usual lags, the ECB said, a comment economists took as a key justification for slowing the pace of hikes.
- with Reuters

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: In the US, the benchmark S & P 500 declined 0.7 per cent to end the session at 4,061. It was its fourth-straight session of declines. The Nasdaq declined 0.5 per cent to 11,966, while the Dow Jones Industrial Average declined 0.9 per cent to 33,127. The sell-off came as fears grew about the strength of the US banking sector. PacWest's stock slumped more than 40 per cent in afternoon trading, dropping to a record low. Western Alliance shares pared losses after plummeting by nearly 60 per cent following a Financial Times report that the lender was exploring strategic options, including a potential sale of all or part of its business. However, Western Alliance denied the report, calling it "categorically false in all respects", and said it was weighing legal options against the newspaper. The bank's stock was down nearly 35 per cent in afternoon trading. Western Alliance has been seeking to reassure investors about its financial stability. It comes as First Republic's collapse, the third major casualty of the biggest crisis to hit the US banking sector since 2008, rekindled a slide in shares of regional lenders this week despite regulatory efforts to staunch the turmoil that began with the collapse of Silicon Valley Bank in March. US officials at the federal and state levels are assessing the possibility of "market manipulation" behind big moves in banking share prices in recent days, Reuters has reported. "Nobody knows where these banks should be trading at because what we saw with Silicon Valley Bank is that the fundamentals can change so quickly," Tom Plumb, portfolio manager at Plumb Balanced Fund said. "This normally would have been a great opportunity to buy banks with premier regional presence and it may be, but the real concern is nobody knows what the rules are and what they are valued at," Mr Plumb added. The KBW Regional Banking index dropped 3.3 per cent. Major U.S. banks were also losing ground on Thursday, with the S & P 500 Banks index falling nearly 3 per cent. JPMorgan's shares fell 1.4 per cent, while Bank of America declined 3 per cent. The common theme among the banking stocks that have sold off sharply is that they reported large deposit declines in the first quarter, said Truist Securities analyst Brandon King, while calling the sell-off "overdone." PacWest Bancorp reported a loss of $1.1 billion attributed to shareholders for the first quarter of the year. - with Reuters
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Wall Street drops on banking worries

children.content: In the US,
the benchmark S
P 500 declined 0.7 per cent to end the session at 4,061.
It was its fourth-straight session of declines.
The Nasdaq declined 0.5 per cent to 11,966, while the Dow Jones Industrial Average declined 0.9 per cent to 33,127.
The sell-off came as fears grew about the strength of the US banking sector.
PacWest's
stock slumped more than 40 per cent in afternoon trading, dropping to a record low.
Western Alliance

shares pared losses after plummeting by nearly 60 per cent following a Financial Times report that the lender was exploring strategic options, including a potential sale of all or part of its business.
However,
Western Alliance denied the report, calling it "categorically false in all respects", and said it was weighing legal options against the newspaper.
The bank's stock was down nearly 35 per cent in afternoon trading.
Western Alliance has been seeking to reassure investors about its financial stability.

It comes as First Republic's collapse, the third major casualty of the biggest crisis to hit the US banking sector since 2008, rekindled a slide in shares of regional lenders this week despite regulatory efforts to staunch the turmoil that began with the collapse of Silicon Valley Bank in March.
US officials at the federal and state levels are assessing the possibility of "market manipulation" behind big moves in banking share prices in recent days,
Reuters has reported.

"Nobody knows where these banks should be trading at because what we saw with Silicon Valley Bank is that the fundamentals can change so quickly," Tom Plumb, portfolio manager at Plumb Balanced Fund said.

"This normally would have been a great opportunity to buy banks with premier regional presence and it may be, but the real concern is nobody knows what the rules are and what they are valued at," Mr Plumb added.
The KBW Regional Banking index
dropped 3.3 per cent.
Major U.S. banks were also losing ground on Thursday, with the S
P 500 Banks index
falling nearly 3 per cent. JPMorgan's shares fell 1.4 per cent, while Bank of America declined 3 per cent.

The common theme among the banking stocks that have sold off sharply is that they reported large deposit declines in the first quarter, said Truist Securities analyst Brandon King, while calling the sell-off "overdone."
PacWest Bancorp reported a loss of $1.1 billion attributed to shareholders for the first quarter of the year.
- with Reuters

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: My colleague Michael Janda has a summary of the RBA's latest economic outlook. He says the outlook brings both bad and good news for Australians. The bad news is that the economy is much weaker, and households suffering much more, than the RBA forecast three months ago. But the good news is that this drop in real household incomes and consumer spending means inflation is coming down slightly faster than the bank previously expected. Before that story's posted online, here's some of the details. Near-term economic forecasts: The RBA says economic growth over the year to June is now expected to be just 1.7 per cent, more than half-a-percentage-point lower than was forecast just three months ago. Things don't improve before the end of this year, with growth of just 1.2 per cent expected over the year to December, down from a previous forecast of 1.6 per cent. Wages won't grow as much as expected: After much hand-wringing about the risk of a prices-wages spiral, the RBA has once again dialled back its forecasts of wages growth over the next two years. It forecasts Australian workers to receive average annual wage rises topping out at 4 per cent by the end of the year, before growth falls back again to 3.7 per cent over the year to June 2025. The broader measure of average earnings per hour — which includes bonuses, promotions and other factors excluded from the Wage Price Index — has seen an even larger cut to its forecasts, as employers report having less trouble finding workers to fill vacancies. The RBA's own business liaison suggests that, "Reported wages growth has stabilised and expectations for wages growth in the next 12 months have moderated." "Contacts report their wages growth has stabilised at around 4 per cent, but expect growth to moderate in the near term."
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: RBA's latest economic forecasts: growth and wages

He says the outlook brings both bad and good news for Australians.
The
bad news
is that the economy is much weaker, and households suffering much more, than the RBA forecast three months ago.
But the
good news
is that this drop in real household incomes and consumer spending means inflation is coming down slightly faster than the bank previously expected.
Before that story's posted online, here's some of the details.
Near-term economic forecasts:
The RBA says
economic growth over the year to June is now expected to be just 1.7 per cent
more than half-a-percentage-point lower than was forecast just three months ago.
Things don't improve before the end of this year,
with growth of just 1.2 per cent expected over the year to December
, down from a previous forecast of 1.6 per cent.
Wages won't grow as much as expected:
After much hand-wringing about the risk of a prices-wages spiral, the RBA has once again dialled back its forecasts of wages growth over the next two years.
It forecasts Australian workers to receive average annual wage rises
topping out at 4 per cent
by the end of the year, before growth falls back again to 3.7 per cent over the year to June 2025.

The broader measure of average earnings per hour — which includes bonuses, promotions and other factors excluded from the Wage Price Index — has seen an even larger cut to its forecasts, as employers report having less trouble finding workers to fill vacancies.
The RBA's own business liaison suggests that, "Reported wages growth has stabilised and expectations for wages growth in the next 12 months have moderated."
"Contacts report their wages growth has stabilised at around 4 per cent, but expect growth to moderate in the near term."

image.altText: A large golden orb spider with a dead micro bat in its web

items.synopsis: Megan Wright has a "healthy respect" for the spiders that live around her home north of Cairns, but admits being "very excited — and horrified" when she noticed a big golden orb spider eating a bat caught in its web.

title.children: Golden orb spider captured eating microbat in Far North Queensland
